Imprisonment of either description for 10 years and fine.
Putting or attempting to put a person in fear of death or grievous hurt in order to commit extortion
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Extortion by threat of accusation of an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for 10 years
Imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
If the offence threatened be an unnatural offence
Putting a person in fear of accusation of offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment for 10 years in order to commit extortion
Imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
If the offence be an unnatural offence
Rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
If committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise
Rigorous imprisonment for 14 years, and fine.
Rigorous imprisonment for 7 years, and fine.
Person voluntarily causing hurt in committing or attempting to commit robbery, or any other person jointly concerned in such robbery
Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
Death, imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
Robbery or dacoity, with attempt to cause death or grievous hurt
Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 7 years
Attempt to commit robbery or dacoity when armed with deadly weapon
Rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
Belonging to a gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing dacoity
Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
Belonging to a wandering gang of persons associated for the purpose of habitually committing thefts
Rigorous imprisonment for 7 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Being one or five or more persons assembled for the purpose of committing dacoity
Dishonest misappropriation of movable property, or converting it to one's own use
Compoundable when permission is given by the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.

Dishonest misappropriation of property, knowing that it was in possession of a deceased person at the time of his death, and that it has not since been in the possession of any person legally entitled to it
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
If by clerk or person employed by deceased
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Compound-able when the value of the property does not exceed two hundred and fifty rupees and permission is given by the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Criminal breach of trust by a carrier, wharfinger, etc.
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Criminal breach of trust by a clerk or servant
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Criminal breach of trust by public servant or by banker, merchant or agent, etc.
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Of the receiving of stolen property
Dishonestly receiving stolen property knowing it to be stolen
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Dishonestly receiving stolen property, knowing that it was obtained by dacoity
Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Assisting in concealment or disposal of stolen property knowing it to be stolen
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Compoundable when permission is given by the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Cheating a person whose interest the offender was bound, either by law or by legal contract, to protect
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Cheating and thereby dishonestly inducing delivery of property, or the making, alteration or destruction of a valuable security
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Cheating public authorities in performance of contracts
Imprisonment of either description for ten years, and fine.
Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Of fraudulent deeds disposition of property
Fraudulent removal or concealment of property, etc, to prevent distribution among creditor
Compoundable when permission is given by the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Fraudulently preventing a from being made available for his creditors a debt or demand due to the offender
Fraudulently execution of deed of transfer containing a false statement of consideration
Compoundable when permis­sion is given by the Court before which the prosecu­tion is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, of fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Fraudulent removal or concealment of property, of himself, or any other person, or assisting in the doing thereof, of dishonestly releasing any demand or claim to which he is entitled
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Compoundable when the only loss or damage caused is loss or damage to a private person
Imprisonment of either description for 3 months, or fine, or both.
Mischief, and thereby causing damage to the amount of 50 rupees or upwards
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal of the value of 10 rupees or upwards
Compoundable when permission is given by the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, of fine, or both.
Mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any elephant, camel, horse, etc, whatever may be its value, or any other animal of the value of 50 rupees or upwards
Imprisonment of either description for 5 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Mischief by causing diminution of supply of water for agricultural purposes, etc
Imprisonment of either description for 5 years, or fine, or both.
Mischief by injury to public road, bridge, navigable river, or navigable channel, and rendering it impassable or less safe for travelling or conveying property
Mischief by causing inundation or obstruction to public drainage, attended with damage
Imprisonment of either description for 5 years, or fine, or both.
Mischief by destroying or moving, etc, a land mark fixed by public authority
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to cause damage to an amount of 100 rupees or upwards, or, in case of agricultural produce, 10 rupees or upwards
Imprisonment which may extend to seven years, and fine. If the damage relates to public property imprisonment shall not be less than five years.
Mischief by fire of explosive substance with intent to destroy a house, etc.
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Mischief committed after preparation made for causing death, or hurt, etc
Imprisonment of cither description for 5 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Imprisonment of either description for 3 months, or fine of 500 rupees, or both.
Imprisonment of either description for one year, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine of 1000 rupees, or both.
House-trespass in order to the commission of an offence punishable with death
Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for 10 years, and fine.
House trespass in order to the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment for life
Imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
House-trespass in order to the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment
Compoundable when permission is given by the Court before which prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, and fine.
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
House-trespass, having made preparation for causing hurt, assault, etc
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, and fine.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, and fine.
Court of Session of Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation made for causing hurt, assault, etc
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night in order to the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment
Imprisonment of either description for 5 years, and fine.-
Imprisonment of either description for 14 years, and fine.
Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night, after preparation made for causing hurt, etc
Imprisonment of either description for 14 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Grievous hurt caused whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking Death or grievous hurt caused by one of several persons jointly concerned in house­breaking by night, etc
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine. Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Court of Session. Court of Session.
Dishonestly breaking open or unfastening any closed receptacle containing or supposed to contain property
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Being entrusted with any closed receptacle containing or supposed to contain any property, and fraudulently opening the same
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
CHAPTER XVIII OFFENCES RELATING TO DOCUMENTS AND TO TRADE OR PROPERTY MARKS
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Forgery of a record of a Court of Justice or of a Register of Births, etc, kept by a public servant
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Forgery of a valuable security, will, or authority to make or transfer any valuable security, or to receive any money, etc.
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
When the valuable security is a promissory note of the Central Government
Forgery for the purpose of cheating
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Forgery for the purpose of harming the reputation of any person, or knowing that it is likely to be used for that purpose
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, and fine.
Using as genuine a forged document which is known to be forged
Punishment for forgery of such document
Same Court as the forgery is triable.
When the forged document is a promissory note of the of Government of India
Punishment for forgery of such document.

Making or counterfeiting a seal, plate, etc, with intent to commit a forgery punishable under section 467 of the Ranbir Penal Code, or possessing with like intent any such seal, plate, etc, knowing the same to be counterfeit
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.

Making or counterfeiting a seal, plate, etc, with intent to commit a forgery punishable otherwise than under section 467 of the Ranbir Penal Code, or possessing with like intent any such seal, plate, etc, knowing the same to be counterfeit
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Having possession of a document, knowing it to be forged, with intent to use it as genuine;
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
If the document is one of the description mentioned in section 467 of the Ranbir Penal Code
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Counterfeiting a device or mark used for authenticating document described in section 467 of the Ranbir Penal Code, or possessing counterfeit marked material
Counterfeiting a device or mark used for authenticating documents other than those described in section 467 of the Ranbir Penal Code, or possessing counterfeit marked material
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Fraudulently destroying or defacing, or attempting to destroy or deface, or secreting, a will, etc
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Using a false of property mark with intent to deceive or injury any person
Compoundable when permission is given by the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Counterfeiting a trade or property mark used by another with intent to cause damage or injury
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Counterfeiting a property mark used by a public servant, or any mark used by him to denote the manufacture, quality, etc, of any property
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, and fine.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Fraudulently making or having possession of any die, plate or other instrument for Counterfeiting any public or private property or trade mark
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Knowingly selling goods marked with a counterfeit property or trade mark
Compoundable with permission of the the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Fraudulently making a false mark upon any package or receptacle containing goods, with intent to cause it to be believed that it contains goods which it does not contain, etc
Imprisonment of either description for 3 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Making use of any such false mark
Removing, destroying or defacing any property-mark with intent to cause injury
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Of currency notes and bank notes
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10. years, and fine.
Using as genuine forged or counterfeit currency notes or bank-notes
Imprisonment for life or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Possession of forged or counterfeit currency notes or bank-notes
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, or fine, or both.
Making or possessing instrument or material for forging or counterfeiting currency notes or bank-notes
Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
CHAPTER XL X CRIMINAL BREACH OF CONTRACTS OF SERVICE
Being bound to attend on or supply the wants of a person who is helpless from youth unsoundness of mind or disease, and voluntarily omitting to do so Omitted
Imprisonment of either description for 6 months, or fine of 200 rupees, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
CHAPTER XX OFFENCES RELATING TO MARRIAGE
A man by deceit causing a woman not lawfully married to him to believe that she is lawfully married to him and to cohabit with him in that belief
Imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
Marrying again during the lifetime of a husband or wife
Compoundable with permission of Court before which the prosecution is pending
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Same offence with concealment of the former marriage from the person with whom subsequent marriage is contracted
Imprisonment of either description for 10 years, and fine.
A person with fraudulent intention going through the ceremony of being married, knowing that he is not thereby lawfully married
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, and fine.
Imprisonment of either description for 5 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Enticing or taking away of detaining with a criminal intent a married woman
Imprisonment of either description for 5 years, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Punishment for subjecting a married woman to cruelty
Imprisonment for three years, and fine.
Judicial Magistrate of the first class.

(a) Defamation against the President or the Vice President or the Governor of a State in India or the Governor of this State or a Minister or any other public servant employed in connection with the affairs of the Union or of a State in respect of his conduct in the discharge of his public functions, when instituted upon a complaint made by the public prosecutor
Compoundable with the permission of the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Simple imprisonment for two years, or fine, or both.
Simple imprisonment for two years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.

Printing or engraving matter knowing it to be defamatory against the President or Vice President or the Governor of a State in India or the Governor of this State or a Minister or any other public servant employed in connection with the affairs of the Union or of a State in respect of his conduct in the discharge of his public functions when instituted upon a complaint made by the public prosecutor
Compoundable with the permission of the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Printing or engraving matter knowing it to be defamatory, in any other case
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.

Sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter, knowing it to contain such matter, against the President or the Vice-President or the Governor of a State in India or the Governor of a State or Minister of any other public servant employed in connection with the affairs of the Union of a State in respect of his conduct in the discharge of his public functions when instituted upon a complaint made by the Public Prosecutor
Compoundable with the permission of the Court before which the prosecution is pending
Simple imprisonment for two years, or fine, or both.
Sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter knowing it to contain such matter, in any case
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
CHAPTER XXII CRIMINAL INTIMIDATION, INSULT AND ANNOYANCE
Insult intended to provoke a breach of the peace
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
(l)False statement, rumour, etc, with intent to cause mutiny or offence against the public peace
Imprisonment which shall not be less than 3 years but may extend to ten years, and fine
(2) False statement, rumour, etc, with intent to create enmity, hatred or ill-will between different classes
(3) False statement, rumour, etc, made in place of worship, etc, with intent to create enmity, hatred or ill will
Imprisonment which shall not be less than 4 years, but may extend to. 10 years, and fine.
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
If threat be to cause death or grievous hurt, etc
Imprisonment of either description for 7 years, or fine, or both.
Court of Session or Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Criminal intimidation by anonymous communication or having taken precaution to conceal whence the threat comes
Imprisonment of either description for 2 years, in addition to the punishment under above section.
Act caused by inducing a person to believe that he will be rendered an object of Divine displeasure
Imprisonment of either description for 1 year, or fine, or both.
Judicial Magistrate of the first or second class.
Uttering any word of making any gesture intended to insult the modesty of a woman, etc
Simple imprisonment which shall not be less than one year but which may extend to three years and with fine
Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Appearing in a public place, etc, in a state of intoxication, and causing annoyance to any person
Simple imprisonment which may extend to two years and with the fine up to one hundred rupees.
CHAPTER XXIII ATTEMPTS TO COMMIT OFFENCES
Attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life and in such attempt doing Act towards the commission of the offence
According as the offence is one in respect of which the police may arrest without warrant or not
According as the offence is one in respect of which a summons or warrant shall ordinarily issue
According as offence contemplated by the offender is bailable or not
Compoundable when the offence attempted is compoundable
Imprisonment for life or imprisonment not exceeding half longest term and of description, provided for the offence, or fine, or both.
The Court by which the offence attempted is triable.

content.p: OFFENCES AGAINST OTHERS LAWS

td.p: If punishable with death, imprisonment for life or imprisonment for more than 7 years
If punishable with imprisonment for 3 years and upwards but not more than 7 years
If punishable with imprisonment for less than 3 years or with fine only

content.p: [See Section 36] ORDINARY POWERS OF MAGISTRATES
I. Ordinary powers of a Judicial Magistrate of the second class:—.--
Powers to arrest or direct the arrest of and to commit to custody a person committing an offence in his presence, section 64.
Power to arrest, or direct the arrest in his presence of, an offender, section 65.
Power to endorse a warrant, or to order the removal of an accused person arrested under a warrant, sections 83, 84 and 86.
Power to issue proclamations in cases judicially before him, section 87.
Power to attach and sell property and to dispose of claims or objections to attached property, section 88.
Power to restore attached property, section 89.
Power to require search to be made for letters and telegrams, section 95.
Power to issue search warrant, section 96.
Power to endorse a search warrant, and order delivery of thing found, section 99.
Power to order the police to investigate an offence in cases in which the Magistrate has jurisdiction to try or commit for trial, section 155.
Power to authorise detention, not being detention in the custody of the police, of a person during a police investigation, section 167.
Power to postpone issue of process and to inquire into a case or direct investigation, section 202.
Power to commit for trial under section 205-C
Power to detain an offender found in the Court, section 351.
Power to take evidence on commission, section 503.
Power to recover forfeited bond for appearance before Magistrate's Court, section 514 and to require fresh security, section 514-A.
Power to make order as to custody and disposal of property pending inquiry or trial, section 516-A.
Power to make order as to disposal of property, section 517.
Power to sell property of a suspected character, section 525.
Power to require affidavit in support of application, section 539-A.
Power to make local inspection, section 539-B.
II. Ordinary powers of Judicial Magistrate of the first class:-.--
The ordinary powers of a Judicial Magistrate of the second class.
Power to direct warrant to land-holders, section 78.
Power to issue search warrant otherwise than in due course of an inquiry, section 98.
Power to issue search warrant for discovery of persons wrongfully confined, section 100.
Power to require execution of a bond, section 106.
Power to discharge sureties, sections 126 and 126-A.
Power to make orders etc. in possession cases, sections 145,146, 147.
Power to record statements and, confessions during a police investigation, section 164.
Power to authorise detention of a person in the custody of the police during a police investigations, section 167.
Power to stop proceedings when no complainant, section 249.
Power to tender pardon to accomplice during inquiry into case by himself, section 337.
Power to make orders of maintenance, sections 488 and 489.
Power to recover penalty on forfeited bond, section 514.
Power to require fresh security, section 514-A.
Power to recall case made over by him to another Magistrate, section 528 (4).
Power to make order as to first offenders, section 562.
Power to order released convicts to notify residence, section 565.
III. Ordinary powers of Chief Judicial Magistrates:—
The ordinary powers of a Judicial Magistrate of the first class.
Powers to require delivery of letters, telegrams, etc., section 95.
Power to issue search warrants for documents in custody of postal or telegraph authorities, section 96.
Power to release persons imprisoned for failing to give security under section 106, section 124.
Power to cancel any bond for keeping the peace under section 106,- section 125.
Power to order Police Investigation into a cognizable case, section 156.
Power to issue process for a person within local jurisdiction who has committed an offence outside the local jurisdiction, section 186.
Power to entertain complaints, section 190.
Power to receive police reports, section 190.
Power to entertain cases without complaint, section 190.
Power to transfer cases to a Subordinate Magistrate, section 192.
Power to order preliminary investigation by a Police Officer not below the rank of an Inspector in certain cases, section 196-B.
Power to try summarily, section 260.
Power to tender pardon to accomplice at any stage of a case, section 337.
Power to pass sentence on proceedings recorded by a Subordinate Magistrate, section 349.
Power to call for records, section 435.
Power to order inquiry, section 436.
Power to order commitment, section 437.
Power to report a case to High Court, section 438.
Power to withdraw cases to try or refer them for trial, section 528.
Power to compel restoration of abducted female, section 552.
IV. Ordinary power of an Executive Magistrate of the second class:—
Power to arrest or direct the arrest of and to commit to custody, a person committing an offence in his presence, section 65.
Power to arrest, or direct the arrest in his presence of, an offender, section 65.
Power to endorse a warrant, or to order the removal of an accused person arrested under a warrant, sections 83,, 84 and 86.
Power to issue proclamations, section 87.
Power to attach and sell property, section 88.
Power to restore attached property, section 89.
Power to require search to be made for letters and telegrams, section 95.
Power to issue search warrant, section 96.
Power to endorse a search warrant and order delivery of thing found, section 99.
Power to command unlawful assembly to disperse, section 127.
Power to use civil force to disperse unlawful assembly, section 128.
Power to require military force to be used to disperse unlawful assembly, section 130.
Power to authorise detention not being detention in the custody of the police of a person during a police investigation, section 167.
Power to take evidence on commission, section 503.
Power to recover forfeited bond for appearance before Magistrate's Court, section 514 and to require fresh security, section 514-A.
Power to make order as to disposal of property, section 517.
Power to sell property of a suspected character, section 525.
V. Ordinary power of an Executive Magistrate of the first class:—
The ordinary powers of an Executive Magistrate of the second class.
Power to issue search warrant otherwise than in course of an inquiry, section 98.
Power to issue search warrant for discovery of persons wrongfully confined, section 100.
Power to require security to keep the peace, section 107.
Power to require security for good behaviour, section 109.
Power to discharge sureties, sections 126 and 126-A.
Power to make orders as to local nuisances, section 133.
Power to authorise detention of a person in the custody of the Police during a police investigation, section 167.
Power to hold inquests, section 176.
Power to recover penalty on forfeited bond, section 514.
Power to require fresh security, section 514-A.
VI. Ordinary powers of a Sub-Divisional Magistrate:—
The Ordinary powers of an Executive Magistrate of the first class.
Power to direct warrants to land-holders, section 78.
Power to require security for good behaviour, section 110.
Power to make orders prohibiting repetitions of nuisances, section 143.
Power to make orders under section 144.
Power to depute Subordinate Executive Magistrate to make local inquiry, section 148.
Power to issue process for person within local jurisdiction who has committed an offence outside the local jurisdiction, section 186.
Power to sell property alleged or suspected to have been stolen etc., section 524.
VII. Ordinary Powers of a District Magistrate:—
The ordinary powers of a Sub-Divisional Magistrate.
Power to require delivery of letters, telegrams, etc., section 95.
Power to issue search warrants for documents in custody of postal or telegraph authorities, section 96.
Power to require security for good behaviour, section 108.
Power to discharge persons bound to keep the peace or to be of good behaviour, section 124.
Power to order preliminary investigation by Police Officer not below the rank of inspector in certain cases, section 196-B.
Power to cancel bond for keeping peace, section 125.
Power to tender pardon to accomplice at any stage of a case, section 337.
Power to call for and examine records, section 425 (2).
Power to direct Executive Magistrate to make further inquiry into proceedings, etc., section 436 (2).
Power to report to High Court, section 438 (3).
Power to appoint person to be Public Prosecutor in particular case, section 492 (2).
Power to compel restoration of abducted female, section 552.
ADDITIONAL POWERS WITH WHICH MAGISTRATE MAY BE INVESTED

item.p: By High Court.-

content.p: Powers with which a Judicial Magistrate of the first class may be invested.
Power to issue process for person within local jurisdiction, who has committed an offence outside the local jurisdiction, section 186.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon complaint, section 190.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon police reports, section 190.
Power to take cognizance of offences without complaint, section 190.
Power to try summarily, section 260.
Omitted.
Powers with which a Judicial Magistrate of the second class may be invested.
Power to record statements and confessions during a Police investigation, section 104.
Power to authorise detention of a person in the custody of the Police during a police investigation, section 167.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon complaint, section 190.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon police reports section 190.
Power to take cognizance of offences without complaint, section 190.
Power to commit for trial, section 206.

blockList.listIntroduction: Power to make orders as to first offenders, section 562.

content.p: Powers with which any Judicial Magistrate of the first class may be invested.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon complaint, section 190.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon police reports section 190.
Powers to transfer cases, section 192.
Powers with which any Judicial Magistrate of the second class may be invested.
Powers to take cognizance of offences upon complaint, section 190.
Power to take cognizance of offences upon police reports section 190.
Power to stop proceedings instituted otherwise than upon complaint, section 249.

blockList.listIntroduction: (Part II)

item.p: By Government.-

content.p: Power with which an Executive Magistrate of the first class may be invested.
Power to take orders prohibiting repetitions of nuisances, section 143.
Power to make orders under section 144.
Power to issue process for person within local jurisdiction, who has committed an offence outside the local jurisdiction, section 186.
Power to sell property alleged or suspected to have been stolen, etc., section 524.
Powers with which an Executive Magistrate of the second class may be invested.
Power to make orders prohibited repetitions of nuisances section 143.
Power to make orders under section 144.
Power to authorise detention of a person in the custody of the police during a police investigation, section 167.
Power to hold inquests, section 174.
Power with which a District Magistrate may be invested.
Power to withdraw cases and to try or refer them for trial, sub-section (3) and (3-A) of section 528.
Power with which a Sub-Divisional Magistrate may be invested.

blockList.listIntroduction: Power to call for records of inferior Court and to forward them to District Magistrate, sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 435.

item.p: By the District Magistrate.--

content.p: Power with which any Executive Magistrate of the first class may be invested.
Power to make orders prohibiting repetition of nuisance, section 143.
Power to make orders under section 144.
Power with which any Executive Magistrate, second class may be invested.
Power to make orders prohibiting repetitions of nuisances, section 143.
Power to make orders under section 144.
Power to hold inquests, section 174.
